value.title: Announcing Dart 3.5, and an update on the Dart roadmap

content.subtitle: It’s time for another of our quarterly Dart SDK releases. We have improvements in interoperability, new features in our pub.dev package…

paragraphs.name: 482a
paragraphs.text: Announcing Dart 3.5, and an update on the Dart roadmap

It’s time for another of our quarterly Dart SDK releases. We have improvements in interoperability, new features in our pub.dev package manager, and we’ve graduated our new web integration APIs to stable and version 1.0.

paragraphs.name: 429e
paragraphs.text: A large portion of our time has been dedicated to larger, multi-quarter efforts, so with that we also have an update on our Dart roadmap, with details on what we hope to make progress on in the coming quarters.

paragraphs.name: b09f
paragraphs.text: Dart 3.5 release image.

paragraphs.name: e2f1
paragraphs.text: New capabilities in Dart 3.5

paragraphs.name: 03c9
paragraphs.text: Dart 3.5 features a number of new capabilities discussed below. There are also a smaller number of changes to core library APIs, and about 10 very minor breaking changes, covered in the changelog.

paragraphs.name: ed5d
paragraphs.text: Web platform and JS interoperability

paragraphs.name: 15f5
paragraphs.text: In Dart 3.4 and Flutter 3.22 we introduced support for compiling Flutter Web apps to WebAssembly. Compilation to WebAssembly requires using our new Dart to JS interop model, which previously was in preview. As of Dart 3.5 it is now considered stable and complete, and we’ve updated the browser API bindings in package:web (which replaces the older dart:html library) to version 1.0.

paragraphs.name: 2baa
paragraphs.text: We’d like to encourage all web package authors to migrate to package:web. We plan on deprecating the old interop APIs (dart:html, dart:js, package:js, etc.) in our next Dart release, and fully discontinuing them later next year. We invite you to offer feedback on this plan in the tracking issue. We also plan on updating the scoring on the pub.dev package manager to award points for web packages that support the new interop model.

We’ve also added a new lint, which validates that your code uses the new JS interop types correctly. We recommend that you add this lint to your analysis_options.yaml file as part of migrating your web packages.

paragraphs.name: cb92
paragraphs.text: Dart native interoperability

paragraphs.name: d30b
paragraphs.text: We’ve also made a range of improvements to our native interoperability, which supports calling directly from Dart into C, Java, Kotlin, Objective-C, and Swift.

paragraphs.name: b089
paragraphs.text: C interop is enabled by our FFI (Foreign Function Interface) library, which we’ve supported for several years. In Dart 3.5, we’ve made incremental improvements to support passing a pointer from Dart TypedData objects directly to FFI, avoiding having to first copy the memory from Dart to Native (details).

paragraphs.name: 0fb5
paragraphs.text: Java & Kotlin interop is enabled by the JNIgen generator (currently in preview), which automates the creation of the bindings code to call from Dart into Java & Kotlin via the Java Native Interface (JNI). We’ve improved performance and added support for Java exceptions and Kotlin top-level functions. We’ve also discontinued the former C-based bindings, as the alternate Dart-only bindings now have comparable performance and features, and are much easier to use, For details, see the changelog.

paragraphs.name: 6abc
paragraphs.text: Objective-C interop builds on top of FFI and our FFIgen generator (currently in preview). We’ve added support for Objective-C protocols, and common types such as NSString. For a large example of a package built with FFIgen, see cupertino_http which interoperates with Apple’s URL Loading System networking library.

We’ll continue to invest in further interoperability — both in terms of completing the above mentioned libraries, and in terms of supporting Swift — over the coming releases. See the roadmap section below for details.

paragraphs.name: a8fc
paragraphs.text: Pub.dev package repository

paragraphs.name: 19db
paragraphs.text: Pub.dev is our package repository where the community can share and find packages with a wealth of functionality. We’ve made a number of improvements here. First we’ve refined the support for topics: the mechanism by which package authors can tag their packages with the category that they belong to (such as widget). We now consolidate common topics that cover the same category but use slight variations in their phrasing (for example widgets vs widget).

paragraphs.name: 4be2
paragraphs.text: Second, we’ve added a new pub unpack command. This offers a quick and easy way to download a package to your file system. This can be used, for example, if you want to run the example program of a package on your local machine:

paragraphs.name: f8d5
paragraphs.text:
$ dart pub unpack path
Downloading path 1.9.0 to `./path-1.9.0`...

$ cd path-1.9.0/example/

$ dart run example.dart
Current path style: posix
Current process path: /Users/mit/tmp/path-1.9.0/example

paragraphs.name: a4eb
paragraphs.text: Third, we’ve added a new pub downgrade --tighten command. This can be used to check all the version constraints in a package’s dependencies. When run, it updates the lower constraint to the lowest version for which pub was able to do a resolution.

paragraphs.name: b39e
paragraphs.text: Dart roadmap update
In addition to the completed features above, we’ve also done work across a large number of areas to make progress on our long-term roadmap.

paragraphs.name: e42d
paragraphs.text: IDE and analyzer performance for large monorepos

paragraphs.name: 0f05
paragraphs.text: A ‘monorepo’ is a common way of structuring the source code for a set of related packages and apps in a single repository, for example as in Flutter’s packages repo. A monorepo isn’t just about the convenience of having all the source code “close together”, but can also be a critical tool to ensure that the individual packages & apps in the repo are mutually compatible.

paragraphs.name: 001b
paragraphs.text: We’ve heard consistent feedback from developers that work in large monorepos, that the performance of our tools, and specifically the analyzer, can be lacking. Our analysis of these issues suggests that the root issue is that we end up loading multiple overlapping analysis contexts for each package and ALL of its dependencies, leading to several copies of the analysis of each package in the monorepo in memory at the same time. We believe the fundamental solution is to create a single, shared resolution of the versions of each dependency in such repos, and are working on such a capability via a new pub feature called workspaces. We’ll have much more to share about this in our next Dart release, but for now you can go ahead and see how this was recently applied to the Flutter engine repo.

paragraphs.name: 554c
paragraphs.text: Pub.dev package repository

paragraphs.name: 031a
paragraphs.text: Users of the pub.dev package repository have long requested improved metrics for how used/downloaded each package is. This can be helpful both for package authors as a signal of how many users are deriving benefit from their work, and for package consumers as a signal of what packages other developers are consuming. We’re happy to share that we’re making good progress on this capability, and hope to have it in preview by end of year.

paragraphs.name: 886b
paragraphs.text: Dart native interop

For the Java and Kotlin interop with JNIgen, we expect to wrap up the core support and graduate from experimental to a stable version 1.0 over the next two quarters. For details, see the JNIgen tracker. For ObjectiveC interop, we have a similar goal; see the Objective-C tracker.

paragraphs.name: 8e19
paragraphs.text: Next up we’re investigating direct interop with Swift code. The initial experimentation looks promising, and we hope to have experimental support added early next year.

paragraphs.name: 061b
paragraphs.text: Native interop and bundling of native source code

paragraphs.name: 044d
paragraphs.text: In many cases direct interop is used to call into APIs that are present in the operating system, which means the APIs are always available on those host platforms. However, in some cases the code that Dart is interoperating with is native source code not included directly on the host, which presents a practical challenge for package authors who use such interop: How do you get that native source code bundled and built without having to push a bunch of manual steps onto the consumers of the package? To support this, we’re exploring a native assets system, which could support publishing Dart packages that contain native source code, along with a standardized protocol for enabling the dart and flutter CLI tools to automate the building and bundling of that source code. We envision that this will enable a new set of interoperability use cases, while at the same time offering an uncomplicated user experience for developers who use packages that rely on native source code.

paragraphs.name: cca5
paragraphs.text: Dart language & macros

paragraphs.name: f48e
paragraphs.text: Most of our time in the Dart language and compiler teams is currently spent on making progress on the very large language feature macros, which we introduced in the Dart 3.4 blog post. As we said at the time, this is a huge undertaking, with the potential to cause regressions in some of our core use cases such as hot reload, so we’re taking a thorough approach, and will likely need several quarters of further work before we can share details of the next step.

paragraphs.name: 7cbf
paragraphs.text: In addition to macros, we’re also concurrently exploring a number of other smaller language features, as documented in the Dart language funnel.

paragraphs.name: b86f
paragraphs.text: Since last fall, we have been rewriting the Dart formatter. The old design worked well for many years, but with the success of Flutter, we want to move to a new style that better works for the kind of declarative code that Flutter users often write. The old formatter wasn’t able to produce that kind of output. The rewrite is close to being done and will ship soon. If you’d like to try it out, pass the experiment flag tall-style (flag instructions). We welcome feedback if you see weird output.

paragraphs.name: 3e20
paragraphs.text: Closing

paragraphs.name: 6b4f
paragraphs.text: That’s all we have for today. We welcome your feedback, both on the roadmap items discussed, and on the new features in Dart 3.5, available from Dart.dev or bundled in today’s Flutter 3.24 release.

topics.description: The good, the bad, the buggy.

23738d481ce8.name: Dart
23738d481ce8.description: Dart is an approachable, portable, and productive language for high-quality apps on any platform. Learn more at https://dart.dev.
